trending.reason: Demonstrates a significant leap in logistics for renewable energy, cutting supply times from 2 hours to just 26 minutes.
For the first time, astronomers have used the JWST to capture 'before and after' images of a supernova, solving a major cosmic mystery.
Samsung has officially announced the launch event for its highly anticipated Apple Vision Pro competitor, signalling a new major player in the XR market.

articles.title: Skyways Drone Cuts Offshore Wind Supply Time From 2 Hours To 26 Mins
articles.excerpt: Skyways has completed the world's first repeated autonomous cargo drone deliveries directly to offshore wind turbines, drastically reducing logistics time and increasing efficiency.
articles.author: GlobeNewswire
articles.fullContent:
The Skyways V2 aircraft demonstrated its long-range delivery capabilities to the Arkona Offshore Windfarm.

Autonomous Drones Revolutionise Offshore Wind Logistics

Skyways, in partnership with RWE and Skyports Drone Services, has successfully executed the first-ever autonomous drone deliveries directly to offshore wind turbines, cutting transport time for essential supplies from two hours to just 26 minutes. The operation took place at the Arkona Windfarm in the Baltic Sea, proving the viability of using long-range unmanned aircraft in harsh marine environments.

A New Era of Efficiency

During a three-week trial, the Skyways V2 aircraft performed automated 50-mile round trips from a base in Germany to the wind farm. The drones carried payloads of up to 10 kilograms (22 pounds) and withstood winds of nearly 30 knots to make precise cargo drops to the turbines. This on-demand service represents a significant improvement over traditional crew transfer vessels, which operate on fixed schedules and take far longer to complete the same journey.

"At Skyways, our mission is simple: deliver what matters, where it matters, when it matters." — Charles Acknin, CEO of Skyways

The project aimed to validate the role of drones in making the offshore supply chain more flexible, efficient, and sustainable. The flights were conducted Beyond Visual Line of Sight (BVLOS), following a predefined flight path without reliance on mobile networks.

Technical Capabilities

26 MinsDelivery Time via Drone
2 HoursDelivery Time via Boat
50 MilesAutomated Round Trip
10 kgCargo Capacity

The Skyways V2 aircraft is a dual-hybrid vehicle, using electric motors for vertical takeoff and landing and a heavy-fuel engine for its long-range cruise. This design gives it an operational range of nearly 500 miles. Over the trial, the aircraft flew more than 2,500 kilometres, accumulating over 65 hours of flight time.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ Autonomous drones reduced delivery times to offshore turbines from 2 hours to 26 minutes.
  • ✔ The successful trials prove the viability of BVLOS drone logistics in harsh offshore environments.
  • ✔ The technology offers a more flexible, efficient, and sustainable alternative to traditional supply vessels.
  • ✔ RWE plans to further integrate cargo drones into its global offshore wind fleet operations.

articles.title: For the First Time, Webb Catches Supernova Before and After
articles.excerpt: In an unprecedented achievement, the James Webb Space Telescope has captured images of a massive star both before and after its cataclysmic supernova explosion.
articles.author: Mashable
articles.fullContent:
A combined Webb and Hubble view of spiral galaxy NGC 1637, where the supernova SN 2025pht occurred.

Webb's Unprecedented View of a Star's Demise

An international team of astronomers has used NASA's James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) to capture the first-ever 'before and after' images of a supernova, identifying the original star that exploded on June 29, 2025. This rare accomplishment provides the clearest look yet at a dying star and may solve a long-standing cosmic mystery.

Solving the 'Red Supergiant Problem'

The supernova, named SN 2025pht, occurred in the galaxy NGC 1637, approximately 40 million light-years from Earth. By analysing archival Webb images of that same region of space, scientists were able to pinpoint the progenitor star. The data revealed it was a massive red supergiant cloaked in a thick shroud of dust.

Artist's illustration of a massive red supergiant star.

This discovery helps explain why astronomers rarely see red supergiants explode, even though models predict they should account for most core-collapse supernovae. The new findings suggest the stars do explode but are often hidden from view by heavy dust clouds, which Webb's infrared vision can penetrate.

"Only now, with [Webb], do we finally have the quality of data and infrared observations that allow us to say precisely the exact type of red supergiant that exploded." — Charlie Kilpatrick, Northwestern University

The star was roughly 100,000 times brighter than the sun, but the dense dust made it appear more than 100 times dimmer in visible light. This marks the first time JWST has been used to directly identify a supernova progenitor star, opening a new era for studying how massive stars live and die.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ JWST captured the first-ever 'before and after' images of a star exploding as a supernova.
  • ✔ The progenitor was a massive red supergiant star, hidden within a thick cloud of dust.
  • ✔ This discovery may solve the mystery of why so few red supergiant supernovae are observed.
  • ✔ Webb's infrared capabilities allow it to see through cosmic dust that obscures other telescopes.

articles.title: Samsung's VR Headset Will Be Unveiled on October 21
articles.excerpt: Samsung has officially announced its next Galaxy event, where it will finally reveal 'Project Moohan,' its highly anticipated XR headset positioned as a direct rival to the Apple Vision Pro.
articles.author: GamesRadar+
articles.fullContent:
Samsung's Project Moohan is expected to challenge Apple's Vision Pro in the high-end XR market.

Samsung Enters the XR Arena with 'Project Moohan'

Samsung has confirmed it will unveil its new extended reality (XR) headset, codenamed 'Project Moohan', on October 21 at an event titled 'Worlds Wide Open'. The announcement positions Samsung to directly compete with Apple's Vision Pro, signalling a new major rivalry in the premium spatial computing market.

A New Partnership for a New Reality

Developed in a landmark partnership with Google and Qualcomm, the headset will be the first device to run on the new Android XR platform, an operating system optimised for immersive experiences. It is powered by Qualcomm's latest Snapdragon XR2+ Gen 2 chip, designed specifically for mixed-reality environments. Samsung describes the device as an 'AI-optimised XR platform' that blends 'everyday utility with immersive new experiences'.

💡 What to Expect: The event, streaming live on Samsung's YouTube channel, is expected to reveal the headset's official name, full specifications, pricing, and availability.

Addressing the Competition

Early reports suggest Project Moohan (rumoured to be commercially named Galaxy XR) aims to improve upon the Apple Vision Pro in key areas. It is rumoured to feature higher resolution displays with over 29 million pixels and a lighter build, weighing around 545 grams compared to the Vision Pro's 600-650 grams. While pricing has not been confirmed, the headset is expected to be more accessible than Apple's $3,499 device. Reservations for the new headset are already open, offering early adopters a $100 credit.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ Samsung will unveil its Apple Vision Pro competitor, codenamed Project Moohan, on October 21.
  • ✔ It is the first device from a partnership between Samsung, Google, and Qualcomm, running the new Android XR platform.
  • ✔ The headset is rumoured to be lighter and have a higher resolution than the Apple Vision Pro.
  • ✔ The launch signals a major new competitor in the high-end spatial computing market.

articles.title: Apple's Upgraded Vision Pro With M5 Chip Still Costs $3,500
articles.excerpt: Apple has announced an upgraded Vision Pro featuring the new M5 processor for significantly faster performance and an improved display, but the premium price remains unchanged.
articles.author: Variety
articles.fullContent:
The upgraded Vision Pro includes the powerful M5 chip and a new Dual Knit Band for comfort.

Apple Boosts Vision Pro with M5 Chip

Apple has announced an upgraded version of the Vision Pro, now equipped with the powerful M5 chip. The refresh delivers a significant leap in performance, a higher refresh rate display, and improved battery life, though the starting price remains firm at $3,499.

Performance and Display Enhancements

The new M5 processor, built on a 3-nanometre process, features a 10-core CPU, a 10-core GPU, and a 16-core Neural Engine for AI tasks that is reportedly 50% faster than its predecessor. This upgrade promises smoother overall performance and sharper visuals. The custom micro-OLED displays now support a higher refresh rate of up to 120Hz, which will reduce motion blur and create a more fluid user experience. The headset still works in tandem with the R1 chip, which processes input from the 12 cameras, five sensors, and six microphones in real-time.

"Apple's Vision Pro refresh lands with meaningful improvements wrapped in the same premium price tag that keeps most mortals at bay." — Yahoo

Design and Battery Improvements

Along with the internal upgrades, Apple has introduced a new Dual Knit Band designed for a more comfortable and balanced fit, available in three sizes. Battery life has also seen an improvement, with the new model offering up to 2.5 hours of general use and up to 3 hours of video playback on a single charge. Despite the meaningful upgrades, the unchanged price point suggests Apple continues to position the Vision Pro primarily as a high-end device for developers and enterprise users rather than the mass market.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ The Apple Vision Pro has been upgraded with the new, more powerful M5 chip.
  • ✔ Key improvements include a faster 10-core CPU/GPU, a 120Hz display refresh rate, and longer battery life.
  • ✔ A new Dual Knit Band is included for improved comfort.
  • ✔ The starting price remains unchanged at $3,499.

articles.title: New Collaboration Sends Drones Flying With Emergency Communications
articles.excerpt: A new force in physical security is emerging through the integration of autonomous drone systems with traditional security devices, significantly enhancing threat detection and protection.
articles.author: ECM Web
articles.fullContent:
Autonomous drones are becoming a transformative tool in modern physical security strategies.

Drones Elevate Physical Security and Emergency Response

The integration of autonomous drones into physical security systems is creating a powerful new layer of protection for critical infrastructure, industrial facilities, and corporate campuses. By combining aerial surveillance with traditional ground-based security, organisations can achieve more comprehensive coverage and dramatically faster response times to threats.

Rapid, Autonomous Threat Assessment

When a security alarm is triggered, an autonomous drone can be dispatched to the location within seconds. This provides security teams with a live video feed and immediate situational awareness before human personnel can arrive on the scene. This capability allows for the quick verification of threats, differentiation from false alarms, and more effective deployment of on-ground resources. Drones can navigate obstacles and access hard-to-reach areas like rooftops, eliminating the blind spots often left by fixed cameras.

"Autonomy is the key benefit that drones integrated with AI can bring to physical security." — Scylla AI

AI-integrated drones can perform tedious monitoring of large areas reliably and continuously. In an emergency, they can provide an autonomous response, such as following a suspect and streaming real-time tracking information to law enforcement. This enhances safety for human responders by identifying potential hazards before they enter a volatile situation.

Beyond Surveillance

The application of drones in emergency response extends beyond just surveillance. They are increasingly used in firefighting to detect hotspots, in police operations for reconnaissance, and in disaster management for rapid damage assessment. In search and rescue missions, drones can locate missing persons and deliver essential supplies to dangerous or inaccessible locations. The mere presence of aerial surveillance also acts as a powerful deterrent to potential intruders.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ Integrating autonomous drones with existing security systems provides a dynamic layer of protection.
  • ✔ Drones offer rapid response to alarms, providing live video feeds and situational awareness within seconds.
  • ✔ AI-powered drones can autonomously patrol large areas, track suspects, and inspect hard-to-reach locations.
  • ✔ The technology improves safety for human responders and acts as a strong deterrent to crime.

articles.title: Hames Sharley Seeks Senior 3D Visualisation Artist in Perth
articles.excerpt: Hames Sharley, a leading multidisciplinary design firm, is seeking a talented and experienced Senior 3D Visualisation Artist to join their creative team in the Perth studio.
articles.author: Hames Sharley
articles.fullContent:
Role Overview

Full-time📍 Perth, WAPosted: Oct 15, 2025

Hames Sharley, a leading national design practice, has an exciting opportunity for a Senior 3D Visualisation Artist to join their supportive and collaborative team in the Perth Studio. This role involves working on a diverse portfolio of high-profile projects across Australia, creating compelling and high-quality architectural visualisations.

Key Responsibilities

  • Produce high-quality 3D architectural imagery, animations, and renderings.
  • Collaborate with architectural and interior design teams to interpret concepts and bring them to life.
  • Manage visualisation workflow from modelling and texturing to lighting and post-production.
  • Contribute to the creative direction of projects and mentor junior artists.
  • Work across a variety of project types including urban design, retail, residential, and commercial.

Required Qualifications

  • Experience: Proven experience in a similar role within an architectural or design practice.
  • Technical Skills: Expertise in 3D Studio Max, V-Ray, Corona, and Adobe Creative Suite (Photoshop, After Effects). Experience with Unreal Engine and other real-time rendering software is highly regarded.
  • Portfolio: A strong portfolio showcasing high-quality architectural visualisation work.
  • Soft Skills: Excellent communication skills, a keen eye for detail, composition, and colour, and the ability to work collaboratively in a team environment.

What We Offer

  • A creative and collaborative studio environment.
  • The opportunity to work on significant and diverse national projects.
  • A commitment to professional development and work-life balance.
  • A culture that is supportive, inclusive, and focused on design excellence.

📍 Location: Perth, Western Australia (In-studio)

Application Instructions

To apply, please submit your CV and a comprehensive portfolio showcasing your best work through the original LinkedIn job posting. A cover letter outlining your suitability for the role is also encouraged.

Key Points

  • Role: Senior 3D Visualisation Artist
  • Key Requirement: Strong portfolio and expertise in 3ds Max, V-Ray, and Adobe Suite.
  • Work Arrangement: Full-time, based in the Perth studio.
  • Company: Hames Sharley, a national multidisciplinary design firm.

articles.title: North Atlantic Ocean Current Is Behaving 'Unpredictably'
articles.excerpt: Scientists warn that the North Atlantic subpolar gyre, a critical ocean current system, is losing stability and approaching a potentially catastrophic tipping point.
articles.author: Sustainability Times
articles.fullContent:
The North Atlantic subpolar gyre plays a critical role in regulating the climate of the Northern Hemisphere.

'The Ocean's Heartbeat Is Faltering': Key Atlantic Current Nears Tipping Point

A massive system of rotating ocean currents in the North Atlantic is behaving erratically and may be approaching a critical tipping point, according to a new analysis. The North Atlantic subpolar gyre (SPG), a key component of the larger Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), has been losing stability since the 1950s, which could lead to its substantial weakening and trigger severe climate disruptions.

Clam Shells as Climate Archives

Researchers analysed the shells of long-living clams, which act like 'tree rings of the ocean', to build a high-resolution picture of the SPG's behaviour over the past 150 years. The data revealed two periods of strong instability, with the most recent one ongoing. This 'critical slowing down' — where the system takes longer to recover from disturbances — is a known precursor to a tipping point.

"It's highly worrying. The subpolar gyre was recently acknowledged as a tipping element. A subpolar gyre weakening can bring substantial climate impacts." — Beatriz Arellano Nava, University of Exeter

The SPG helps transport heat from the tropics, regulating temperatures in Europe and North America. Its weakening or collapse, driven by factors like the melting of the Greenland ice sheet, could lead to more extreme weather events, particularly harsher winters in Europe, dramatic sea-level rise on the U.S. East coast, and shifts in global precipitation patterns.

Global Implications

While a collapse of the SPG would be less catastrophic than a full AMOC collapse, the climate outcomes would be similar, though potentially less intense. The weakening is being driven by an influx of freshwater from melting ice, which disrupts the density-driven circulation. Scientists are now working to deploy autonomous robotic floats to collect more data and refine predictions about how close this critical system is to its tipping point.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ The North Atlantic subpolar gyre (SPG), a major ocean current system, is showing signs of instability.
  • ✔ Scientists warn it is approaching a critical tipping point, which could lead to abrupt weakening.
  • ✔ Potential impacts include harsher winters in Europe and significant sea-level rise in North America.
  • ✔ The instability is linked to global warming and the influx of freshwater from melting polar ice.

articles.title: JWST Spots a Hidden Red Supergiant Just Before It Exploded
articles.excerpt: The James Webb Space Telescope has uncovered a massive red supergiant star just before it went supernova, solving a long-standing cosmic mystery about these stellar giants.
articles.author: ScienceDaily
articles.fullContent:
JWST's infrared view revealed the dust-shrouded red supergiant that other telescopes couldn't see.

Webb Solves Mystery of the Missing Supernovae

A team of astronomers has used the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) to capture the clearest view ever of a massive red supergiant star right before it exploded, solving a major astrophysical puzzle. The discovery, published in The Astrophysical Journal Letters, suggests that many of these stellar explosions were not missing, but merely hidden from view behind thick clouds of dust.

Piercing the Cosmic Dust

For decades, astronomers have been puzzled by the 'red supergiant problem'. Theoretical models predict that these enormous stars should be responsible for the majority of core-collapse supernovae, yet they were rarely observed exploding. This new research shows that these stars do explode, but they are often so heavily cloaked in dust that they are invisible to telescopes that observe in visible light.

"It's the reddest, dustiest red supergiant that we've seen explode as a supernova." — Aswin Suresh, Northwestern University

Using JWST's powerful mid-infrared instruments, the team identified the progenitor star of a supernova named SN 2025pht, which was detected on June 29, 2025. By analysing images of the area taken by Webb *before* the explosion, they pinpointed the source star. It was incredibly bright—about 100,000 times more luminous than our sun—but the thick dust veil made it appear over 100 times dimmer than it actually was.

A New Era of Discovery

This is the first time that JWST has been used to identify a supernova's source star, opening a new window into the final moments of massive stars. By being able to see through the cosmic dust, astronomers can now finally close the gap between theory and observation, gaining a more complete picture of how the most massive stars in the universe live and die.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ JWST has identified a massive red supergiant star just before it exploded as a supernova.
  • ✔ The star was hidden behind a thick cloud of cosmic dust, which explains why such events are rarely seen.
  • ✔ This finding helps solve the long-standing 'red supergiant problem' in astrophysics.
  • ✔ Webb's infrared vision is crucial for observing these dust-shrouded stellar events.

videos.title: FIGURE 03 is HERE: A Humanoid Robot That Changes EVERYTHING
videos.excerpt: Figure AI has unveiled Figure 03, its third-generation humanoid robot designed to be a general-purpose partner in homes and factories, capable of performing a wide range of everyday chores autonomously.

videos.title: Icy Moon Ocean Life? New Star Type by JWST? Plus Solar Rain
videos.excerpt: New data from Saturn's icy moon Enceladus reveals complex organic molecules, strengthening the case for potential habitability in its hidden subsurface ocean.
